expanded_description: Speed and velocity describe how fast an object is moving. Though often used interchangeably in everyday language, they are distinct concepts in physics: speed is a scalar (magnitude only), while velocity is a vector (magnitude and direction).

core_concept.principle: Speed measures how fast an object covers distance (rate of distance traveled). Velocity measures how fast an object's position changes and in what direction (rate of displacement). Speed is always positive; velocity can be positive, negative, or zero.
core_concept.explanation: Both speed and velocity involve the concept of 'rate'—how much something changes per unit time. Speed = distance/time tells how much ground is covered per second, regardless of direction. Velocity = displacement/time tells how much position changes per second, including direction. A car going 60 km/h eastward has speed 60 km/h (scalar) and velocity 60 km/h east (vector). Understanding this distinction is crucial: objects can have the same speed but different velocities if moving in different directions. Average speed uses total distance; average velocity uses net displacement.

image.alt: Diagram showing two cars with same speed but different velocities due to opposite directions
image.caption: Speed (scalar): how fast. Velocity (vector): how fast and which direction

sections.introduction: Speed is the most familiar measure of how fast something moves. It tells us the rate at which distance is covered.

key_concept.definition: Speed is the distance traveled per unit time. It is a scalar quantity (magnitude only, no direction) that measures the rate of motion. Mathematically: $\text{speed} = \frac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}}$ or $v = \frac{d}{t}$
key_concept.context: Speed answers 'how fast?' without regard to direction. A speedometer shows speed—it tells you how fast you're going but not which direction. Speed is always positive or zero, never negative.

principles.statement: Since distance is always positive and time is always positive, speed is always positive or zero. There's no such thing as 'negative speed.'
principles.application: Speed magnitude tells how fast, but gives no directional information.
principles.example: Car going 50 km/h north has speed 50 km/h. Car going 50 km/h south also has speed 50 km/h. Same speed, different directions.

principles.principle: Speed Measures Rate of Distance Coverage
principles.statement: Speed tells how much distance is covered per unit time.
principles.application: Higher speed means more distance covered in same time, or same distance covered in less time.
principles.example: Speed 20 m/s means covering 20 meters every second. In 5 seconds at this speed, you cover 20 × 5 = 100 m.

principles.statement: Speed has units of distance divided by time: m/s, km/h, cm/s, mi/h, etc.
principles.application: Always include units. Different units appropriate for different situations.
principles.example: Walking: 1.4 m/s or 5 km/h. Highway driving: 100 km/h or 28 m/s. Sound: 343 m/s. Light: 3 × 10⁸ m/s.

examples.explanation: $v_{\text{avg}} = \frac{\text{total distance}}{\text{total time}}$
Drive 300 km in 4 hours. Average speed = 300 km / 4 h = 75 km/h. This doesn't mean you went exactly 75 km/h the whole time—it's the average over the trip.
Walk 2 km in 30 min, rest 10 min, walk 3 km in 45 min. Total distance = 5 km, total time = 85 min. Average speed = 5 km / 85 min ≈ 3.5 km/h.

characteristics: Speed at a single instant in time
What speedometer reads at that moment
classifications.behavior: Changes from moment to moment during motion.

examples.explanation: At 2:15 PM, speedometer reads 85 km/h. That's your instantaneous speed at that exact moment.
Car accelerating: at $t = 0$ s, speed = 0 km/h. At $t = 5$ s, speed = 30 km/h. At $t = 10$ s, speed = 60 km/h. Different instantaneous speeds at different times.
SI unit. Used in physics calculations. Walking ≈ 1.4 m/s, running ≈ 5 m/s.
Common for vehicles, travel. Speed limits: 50 km/h (urban), 100 km/h (highway).
Used in USA. Highway speed limit: 65 mph ≈ 105 km/h.
Small speeds, laboratory. Snail: 0.05 cm/s.

classifications.note: Conversion: 1 m/s = 3.6 km/h. To convert km/h to m/s, divide by 3.6. To convert m/s to km/h, multiply by 3.6.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Average Speed
worked_examples.problem: A cyclist travels 45 km in 2.5 hours. Calculate the average speed in (a) km/h, (b) m/s.

step_by_step.explanation: Convert units first: 45 km = 45,000 m, 2.5 h = 9000 s

worked_examples.concept_applied: Average speed = total distance / total time. Convert units using: km/h ÷ 3.6 = m/s.

worked_examples.title: Finding Distance from Speed and Time
worked_examples.problem: A car travels at constant speed of 25 m/s for 8.0 seconds. How far does it travel?

step_by_step.explanation: (m/s) × s = m ✓ Correct units for distance

worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange $v = d/t$ to get $d = vt$ when finding distance from speed and time.

worked_examples.title: Finding Time from Speed and Distance
worked_examples.problem: An airplane traveling at 250 m/s needs to cover 1500 km. How long will the trip take?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange to $t = d/v$ when finding time. Convert units to match before calculating.

worked_examples.title: Average Speed with Multiple Segments
worked_examples.problem: A person walks 3 km in 40 minutes, then jogs 5 km in 30 minutes. Find the average speed for the entire trip in km/h.

step_by_step.explanation: Average speed ≠ average of the two speeds. Must use total distance / total time.

worked_examples.concept_applied: For average speed over multiple segments: sum all distances, sum all times, divide totals. Don't just average the individual speeds!

image.alt: Diagram showing distance-time relationship and speed calculation
image.caption: Speed = distance/time. Greater distance in same time = higher speed

sections.introduction: Velocity extends the concept of speed by including direction. It tells us not just how fast an object moves, but which way it's moving.

key_concept.definition: Velocity is the displacement per unit time. It is a vector quantity (magnitude and direction) that measures the rate of position change. Mathematically: $\vec{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$ or velocity = $\frac{x_f - x_i}{t_f - t_i}$
key_concept.context: Velocity answers 'how fast and which direction?' The magnitude of velocity is speed; the direction is indicated by + or - sign (1D) or directional notation (2D/3D). Velocity can be positive, negative, or zero. Positive velocity means moving in positive direction; negative velocity means moving in negative direction.

principles.statement: Velocity measures how quickly position changes, including direction of change.
principles.application: Use displacement (not distance) when calculating velocity.
principles.example: Walk 50 m east in 25 s: velocity = +50 m / 25 s = +2 m/s (2 m/s eastward). Walk 50 m west in 25 s: velocity = -50 m / 25 s = -2 m/s (2 m/s westward). Different velocities even though same speed.

principles.principle: Velocity Can Be Positive, Negative, or Zero
principles.statement: Sign of velocity indicates direction. Positive = moving in positive direction. Negative = moving in negative direction. Zero = stationary.
principles.application: Sign matters! Opposite signs mean opposite directions.
principles.example: $v = +15 \text{ m/s}$: moving 15 m/s in positive direction. $v = -10 \text{ m/s}$: moving 10 m/s in negative direction. $v = 0 \text{ m/s}$: not moving.

principles.statement: Objects with same speed but different directions have different velocities.
principles.application: Direction distinguishes velocities even when speeds match.
principles.example: Two cars both going 60 km/h: one north (+60 km/h), one south (-60 km/h). Same speed (60 km/h), opposite velocities.

principles.statement: The magnitude (absolute value) of velocity equals speed.
principles.example: If $v = -25 \text{ m/s}$, then speed $= |{-25}| = 25 \text{ m/s}$. If $v = +30 \text{ m/s}$, then speed $= |{+30}| = 30 \text{ m/s}$.

classifications.value: Velocity over an interval of time
characteristics: Can be zero even if object moved

examples.explanation: $v_{\text{avg}} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_i}{t_f - t_i}$
At $t_i = 2$ s, position $x_i = 10$ m. At $t_f = 7$ s, position $x_f = 60$ m. $v_{\text{avg}} = \frac{60 - 10}{7 - 2} = \frac{50}{5} = +10 \text{ m/s}$
Walk away and back in 10 seconds, returning to start. Displacement = 0. $v_{\text{avg}} = \frac{0}{10 \text{ s}} = 0 \text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is zero even though you moved!

characteristics: Direction and speed at that moment

examples.explanation: At $t = 3$ s, car is moving at +25 m/s (25 m/s in positive direction). That's instantaneous velocity at that moment.
Ball thrown upward: initially $v = +20$ m/s (upward), slows to $v = 0$ at peak, then $v = -20$ m/s (downward). Instantaneous velocity changes throughout.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Average Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A car starts at position $x_i = 20$ m at time $t_i = 0$ s. At time $t_f = 5$ s, it's at position $x_f = 120$ m. Find the average velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Positive velocity means moving in positive direction at average rate of 20 m/s.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Average velocity = displacement / time interval. Positive result indicates motion in positive direction.

worked_examples.title: Negative Velocity
worked_examples.problem: An object moves from $x_i = 80$ m to $x_f = 30$ m in 10 seconds. Find the average velocity.

step_by_step.calculation: Negative displacement: moved in negative direction

step_by_step.explanation: Negative velocity means moving in negative direction (e.g., leftward if right is positive, or downward if up is positive) at rate of 5 m/s.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Negative displacement gives negative velocity, indicating motion in negative direction.

worked_examples.title: Zero Average Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A person walks from $x = 0$ to $x = 50$ m, then back to $x = 0$, taking 80 seconds total. Find (a) average speed, (b) average velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Displacement: $\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 0 - 0 = 0$ m (returned to start)
Average speed = 1.25 m/s (based on total distance). Average velocity = 0 m/s (based on zero displacement). They differ because path matters for speed but not for velocity.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Average speed = 1.25 m/s, (b) Average velocity = 0 m/s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Round trip: distance > 0 but displacement = 0. Average speed > 0 but average velocity = 0.

worked_examples.title: Finding Position from Velocity
worked_examples.problem: An object starts at $x_i = 15$ m and travels with constant velocity $v = +8$ m/s for 6 seconds. What is its final position?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Displacement = velocity × time. Final position = initial position + displacement.

worked_examples.title: Opposite Velocities, Same Speed
worked_examples.problem: Car A travels at velocity $+25$ m/s. Car B travels at velocity $-25$ m/s. Compare their speeds and directions.

step_by_step.explanation: Speed = |velocity|. Speed of A = |+25| = 25 m/s. Speed of B = |-25| = 25 m/s.
Both have the same speed: 25 m/s. They're moving equally fast.
Car A: positive velocity → moving in positive direction. Car B: negative velocity → moving in negative direction.
Same speed, opposite directions → different velocities.

worked_examples.final_answer: Both cars have speed 25 m/s (same). They have opposite velocities because they're moving in opposite directions.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Same speed doesn't mean same velocity. Direction matters for velocity but not for speed.

image.alt: Diagram showing objects with same speed but opposite velocities
image.caption: Velocity includes direction: positive velocity (→) vs negative velocity (←)

sections.introduction: Understanding when to use speed versus velocity, and how they relate, is essential for solving kinematics problems correctly.

key_concept.definition: Speed and velocity both describe rate of motion, but speed is scalar (uses distance) and velocity is vector (uses displacement). Speed = |average velocity| only for straight-line motion in one direction.
key_concept.context: Choose speed when direction doesn't matter (how fast you're going). Choose velocity when direction matters (how your position is changing). In physics problems, velocity is usually more useful because it contains more information.

examples.explanation: Speedometer readings, race times, 'how fast did I run?' questions.
$\text{speed} = \frac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}}$
Speed is always ≥ 0. If you see negative speed, it's an error.

characteristics: Can be positive, negative, or zero

examples.explanation: Physics problems, calculating position changes, analyzing motion graphs.
$v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_i}{\Delta t}$
$v > 0$: positive direction. $v < 0$: negative direction. $v = 0$: stationary.

characteristics: Equal only for straight-line, one-direction motion

examples.explanation: Move from $x = 0$ to $x = 100$ m in 10 s. Distance = 100 m, displacement = +100 m. Speed = 10 m/s, velocity = +10 m/s. Magnitudes equal.
Move from $x = 0$ to $x = 50$ m to $x = 20$ m in 10 s. Distance = 80 m, displacement = +20 m. Average speed = 8 m/s, average velocity = +2 m/s. Different values.

worked_examples.title: When Speed ≠ |Velocity|
worked_examples.problem: A runner runs 400 m around a circular track in 80 seconds, returning to the start. Find (a) average speed, (b) average velocity magnitude.

step_by_step.explanation: Average speed = 5 m/s. |Average velocity| = |0| = 0 m/s. Not equal because motion involved direction changes (circular path).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Average speed = 5 m/s, (b) Average velocity magnitude = 0 m/s. Different due to circular path.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For non-straight paths or round trips, average speed ≠ |average velocity|.

image.alt: Table comparing properties of speed and velocity
image.caption: Speed vs Velocity: scalar vs vector, distance vs displacement, always positive vs can be negative

sections.introduction: Speed and velocity concepts appear throughout everyday life and scientific applications.

categories.description: Vehicles and travel use both concepts.

examples.explanation: Shows instantaneous speed (how fast right now). Doesn't indicate direction—that's from steering wheel/compass.
Calculates velocity (speed and direction toward destination). 'Heading northeast at 80 km/h.'
Posted limits are maximum speed (scalar). Applies regardless of direction.

categories.description: Athletic performance measured by speed and velocity.

examples.explanation: Time = 10 s. Speed = 10 m/s. Velocity = +10 m/s (forward direction). Straight line, so speed = |velocity|.
Pitcher throws at 95 mph. That's speed. Velocity includes direction (toward batter).
Complete lap: average speed > 0 (covered distance), average velocity = 0 (returned to start).
Velocity (with direction) needed to predict landing point. Speed alone insufficient.
Velocities (with directions) determine collision outcomes. Opposite velocities → head-on collision.
Satellite velocity (speed and direction) keeps it in orbit. Wrong direction = wrong orbit.

summary: Speed measures how fast an object covers distance: speed = distance/time. It is a scalar quantity (magnitude only) that is always positive or zero. Units include m/s, km/h, cm/s. Average speed uses total distance and total time; instantaneous speed is speed at a specific moment. Velocity measures how fast position changes including direction: $v = \Delta x / \Delta t = (x_f - x_i)/(t_f - t_i)$. It is a vector quantity (magnitude and direction) that can be positive (moving in positive direction), negative (moving in negative direction), or zero (stationary). Average velocity uses displacement and time interval; instantaneous velocity is velocity at a specific moment. Key distinctions: Speed uses distance (scalar, always positive), velocity uses displacement (vector, can be negative). Speed = |velocity| (magnitude of velocity). For straight-line motion in one direction, average speed = |average velocity|. For paths with direction changes or round trips, average speed > |average velocity|. Objects with same speed but different directions have different velocities. In physics problems, velocity is typically more useful because it includes directional information necessary for predicting future motion. Converting between units: 1 m/s = 3.6 km/h (multiply by 3.6 to convert m/s to km/h; divide by 3.6 to convert km/h to m/s). Formula rearrangements: from $v = d/t$, get $d = vt$ or $t = d/v$. From $v = \Delta x / \Delta t$, get $\Delta x = v \Delta t$ or $\Delta t = \Delta x / v$.
